summary: An imposing black structure provides a connection between the past and the future in this enigmatic adaptation of a short story by revered sci-fi author Arthur C. Clarke. When Dr. Dave Bowman (Keir Dullea) and other astronauts are sent on a mysterious mission, their ship's computer system, HAL, begins to display increasingly strange behavior, leading up to a tense showdown between man and machine that results in a mind-bending trek through space and time.

Although it raises far more questions than it bothers to answer, Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey is a visual and technical marvel from beginning to end. Anything I could say about this movie has most likely already been said. Although one thing I wanted to mention was that 2001 is 149 minutes long and yet 88 minutes of the thing are dialogue-free, which in itself is both pretty ballsy and utterly magnificent in letting visuals tell a story, a story with plenty of holes but many opportunities for answers.

Equal amounts optimistic as it is harrowing, 2001 is pure brilliance that blurs that line between science fiction and scientific reality; an unforgettable endeavour into the realms of space, humanity and beyond. Putting it bluntly, 2001 is genre-defining for a reason.
